messageBody:
> From: Johannes Link [mailto:john.link@...]
>
> Test theory says that's not possible in the general case.
> Binder [Binder00] calls that the antiextensionality axiom. He
> states "that a test suite that covers one implementation of a
> specification does not necessarily cover a different
> implementation of the same specification".
>
> I interpret "not necessarily" as "there's no such thing in
> the general case". One short example which is hopefully
> obvious enough this time. Consider a function for sorting an
> array of String objects:

[Snipping a bunch of stuff]

In reality, you *can* have the best of both worlds. The
issue at hand is that a general test case excercises all the
contracts that the public interface has. A contract is a
guarantee that the class must satisfy.

I start my tests at the general case. If someone reports
a bug to me where a particular implementation goofs up
internally, I add a testcase that reproduces the problem.
I am careful to make sure that the testcase does not
introduce additional "undocumented" contracts to how the
class is used. In practice, it's not that hard. A bug is
when the class fails to live up to its contracts anyway.

When I am done, I have the benefit of the general testcase
plus the new regression test that is added due to the bug.
The regression test has the added benefit of ensuring the
particular circumstance that caused the bug in the first
implementation doesn't creep back in.

If what you are talking about is different than what I just
described, perhaps it is because we're not speaking the same
language?
